item.title: North Korea Launches Cruise Missiles Into Yellow Sea
item.description: Pyongyang fired several cruise missiles shortly after a U.S. nuclear submarine left the Korean Peninsula.

item.title: U.S. Beats Vietnam, 3-0, in Women's World Cup Opener
item.description: Sophia Smith scored two goals but the Americans squandered many chances in a match in which they dominated possession.

item.title: Is Fruit Getting Sweeter?
item.description: Bred to contain more sugar, today’s cherries, bananas and apples taste different than they used to—but not necessarily better.

item.title: FTX sued Bankman-Fried and other former executives, seeking to recover over $1 billion that they allegedly misappropriated from the firm.
item.description: FTX sued Bankman-Fried and other former executives, seeking to recover over $1 billion that they allegedly misappropriated from the firm.

item.title: The Biden administration said it reached a deal with big tech companies to put more safeguards around artificial intelligence as part of its efforts to rein in misinformation and other risks of the rapidly growing technology.
item.description: The Biden administration said it reached a deal with big tech companies to put more safeguards around artificial intelligence as part of its efforts to rein in misinformation and other risks of the rapidly growing technology.

item.title: Trump's criminal trial over his handling of classified documents is set to start in May, a federal judge said, underscoring his challenge in waging courtroom battles during his bid to win back the presidency in 2024.
item.description: Trump’s criminal trial over his handling of classified documents is set to start in May, a federal judge said, underscoring his challenge in waging courtroom battles during his bid to win back the presidency in 2024.

item.title: The FBI wrongfully searched a foreign-intelligence database for information about a U.S. senator last year, a federal surveillance court said, a disclosure that could fuel an effort in Congress to overhaul the spying program.
item.description: The FBI wrongfully searched a foreign-intelligence database for information about a U.S. senator last year, a federal surveillance court said, a disclosure that could fuel an effort in Congress to overhaul the spying program.

item.title: The DOJ accused Bankman-Fried of seeking to discredit a former member of his inner circle who is expected to testify against him at his coming fraud trial.
item.description: The DOJ accused Bankman-Fried of seeking to discredit a former member of his inner circle who is expected to testify against him at his coming fraud trial.

item.title: The Dow eked out its tenth straight daily gain Friday, notching its longest winning streak in nearly six years and showing how the rally in stocks is spreading from a few chip makers and highflying tech firms into other corners of the economy.
item.description: The Dow eked out its tenth straight daily gain Friday, notching its longest winning streak in nearly six years and showing how the rally in stocks is spreading from a few chip makers and highflying tech firms into other corners of the economy.

item.title: Russian investigators arrested a prominent right-wing critic of Putin, amid a broader crackdown against avowed Russian patriots who have attacked Putin for failing to pursue his war in Ukraine with enough vigor.
item.description: Russian investigators arrested a prominent right-wing critic of Putin, amid a broader crackdown against avowed Russian patriots who have attacked Putin for failing to pursue his war in Ukraine with enough vigor.

item.title: The U.S. military said it is sending additional warships and Marines to the Middle East in an effort to deter Iran from seizing more ships in the region.
item.description: The U.S. military said it is sending additional warships and Marines to the Middle East in an effort to deter Iran from seizing more ships in the region.

item.title: Amazon has told employees across the company that they may have to relocate to main offices concentrated in bigger cities.
item.description: Amazon has told employees across the company that they may have to relocate to main offices concentrated in bigger cities.

item.title: The U.K.'s ruling Conservative Party lost special elections in two of its strongholds as voters expressed anger with a stagnant economy and high inflation.
item.description: The U.K.’s ruling Conservative Party lost special elections in two of its strongholds as voters expressed anger with a stagnant economy and high inflation.

item.title: Ukraine is set to nationalize a bank controlled by two Russian businessmen, denying them a financial haven and seeking to curb their influence on Kyiv's economy and politics.
item.description: Ukraine is set to nationalize a bank controlled by two Russian businessmen, denying them a financial haven and seeking to curb their influence on Kyiv’s economy and politics.

item.title: The FTC said it is pausing its in-house trial against Microsoft's takeoverof Activision Blizzard, giving the agency time to evaluate its next move.
item.description: The FTC said it is pausing its in-house trial against Microsoft’s takeover of Activision Blizzard, giving the agency time to evaluate its next move.

item.title: Russia's central bank raised its key interest rate for the first time since shortly after the invasion of Ukraine.
item.description: Russia’s central bank raised its key interest rate for the first time since shortly after the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: What's News: World-Wide
item.description: What’s News: World-Wide

item.title: What's News: Business & Finance
item.description: What’s News: Business & Finance

item.title: The Horrible Performance Review That Set Him on the Road to CEO
item.description: John Peyton led Dine Brands, the owner of Applebee’s and IHOP, through the pandemic as a rookie chief executive. But first, he had to get the job. Here’s the path he took to get there.

item.title: Why America's Largest Tool Company Couldn't Make a Wrench in America
item.description: A highly automated Texas factory was supposed to bring the manufacturing of Craftsman mechanics’ tools back to American shores. The $90 million project was doomed by equipment problems and slow production.
